 24: """Rescale matrix so that its spectrum fits into the interval [-1, 1]. Also,


 25: rescale the results obtained by the kernel polynomial method back to the


 26: original spectrum.


 27: 


 28: To do:


 29: --> support other matrix formats besides CSR (e.g. dense matrices)


 30: --> support expansions in more than one variable (multivariate functions)


 31: 


 32: Background: The kernel polynomial method (KPM) [1] uses a series expansion


 33: technique using Chebychev polynomials. These polynomials are defined only


 34: on the interval [-1, 1].


 35: 


 36: [1] Weiße et al., Rev. Mod. Phys. 78, 275 (2006)"""

 * def rescale(mat, erange=None, params=None, omp=True, num_threads=None,             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 *             eps=0., copy=True):

static PyObject *__pyx_pf_3kpm_4resc_rescale(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_3kpm_4resc_rescale[] = "mat, (a, b) = rescale(mat, erange=None, params=None, omp=True,\n                             num_threads=None, eps=0., copy=True)\n    a, b = rescale(mat, erange=None, params=None, omp=True,\n                   num_threads=None, eps=0., copy=False)\n\n    Rescale the given matrix in-place. Specify either an energy range \"erange\"\n    (2-tuple) or directly the scaling parameters \"params\" (2-tuple). If \"omp\"\n    is True, use parallel for-loops (OpenMP). If \"num_threads\" is not None, set\n    the number of threads. If the number of threads is smaller than 1,\n    determine and use the number of processor cores.\n\n    The matrix will be rescaled in-place like mat=(mat-b)/a, if a and b are the\n    two scaling parameters. Instead of the parameters itself, an energy range\n    can be specified. The eigenspectrum of the matrix should fit well into the\n    given energy range. The scaling parameters are then calculated via\n    a=(emax-emin)/(2-eps) and b=(emax+emin)/2, where (emin, emax) is the given\n    energy range. An additional small number \"eps\" can be specified to get sure\n    that the spectrum lies well inside the chosen energy range. For the Jackson\n    kernel (see the submodule \"kern\"), eps=pi/limit is said to be an excellent\n    choice [1], where limit is the number of moments (truncation limit) of the\n    Chebychev expansion.\n\n    This function delegates the actual work to one of the low-level functions,\n    all beginning with \"_rescale_\", depending on the matrix type, data type and\n    OpenMP-parallelization requirements. If no appropriate low-level function\n    is found, then the plain Python implementation \"_rescale\" is used.\n\n    [1] Wei\303\237e et al., Rev. Mod. Phys. 78, 275 (2006).\n    ";

 64:     """mat, (a, b) = rescale(mat, erange=None, params=None, omp=True,


 65:                              num_threads=None, eps=0., copy=True)


 66:     a, b = rescale(mat, erange=None, params=None, omp=True,


 67:                    num_threads=None, eps=0., copy=False)


 68: 


 69:     Rescale the given matrix in-place. Specify either an energy range "erange"


 70:     (2-tuple) or directly the scaling parameters "params" (2-tuple). If "omp"


 71:     is True, use parallel for-loops (OpenMP). If "num_threads" is not None, set


 72:     the number of threads. If the number of threads is smaller than 1,


 73:     determine and use the number of processor cores.


 74: 


 75:     The matrix will be rescaled in-place like mat=(mat-b)/a, if a and b are the


 76:     two scaling parameters. Instead of the parameters itself, an energy range


 77:     can be specified. The eigenspectrum of the matrix should fit well into the


 78:     given energy range. The scaling parameters are then calculated via


 79:     a=(emax-emin)/(2-eps) and b=(emax+emin)/2, where (emin, emax) is the given


 80:     energy range. An additional small number "eps" can be specified to get sure


 81:     that the spectrum lies well inside the chosen energy range. For the Jackson


 82:     kernel (see the submodule "kern"), eps=pi/limit is said to be an excellent


 83:     choice [1], where limit is the number of moments (truncation limit) of the


 84:     Chebychev expansion.


 85: 


 86:     This function delegates the actual work to one of the low-level functions,


 87:     all beginning with "_rescale_", depending on the matrix type, data type and


 88:     OpenMP-parallelization requirements. If no appropriate low-level function


 89:     is found, then the plain Python implementation "_rescale" is used.


 90: 


 91:     [1] Weiße et al., Rev. Mod. Phys. 78, 275 (2006).


 92:     """


 93:     __created__ = '2012-08-13'

(However, most of\n    the time one should have a fairly good idea of the (energy) range already\n    from the model that is used.)\n\n    A small factor \"extra\" may be given, the returned (energy) range is\n    enlarged by that factor to be sure that the whole (energy) spectrum of the\n    given matrix is really contained in the returned range.\n    ";

static char __pyx_doc_3kpm_4resc_5erange2params[] = "a, b = erange2params(erange, eps=0.)\n\n    Calculate the scaling parameters \"a\" and \"b\" from the given energy range\n    (2-tuple), like a=(emax-emin)/(2-eps) and b=(emax+emin)/2, where (emin,\n    emax) is the given energy range \"erange\". An additional small number \"eps\"\n    can be specified to make sure that the spectrum lies well inside the chosen\n    energy range. For the Jackson kernel (see the submodule \"kern\"),\n    eps=pi/limit is said to be an excellent choice [1], where limit is the\n    number of moments (truncation limit) of the Chebychev expansion.\n\n    [1] Wei\303\237e et al., Rev. Mod. Phys. 78, 275 (2006).\n    ";
